p: Scanning electron microscopy analysis ( Figure 3) shows that Mn4 ( Figure 3a) was formed by particle aggregates small in size compared to Mn8 ( Figure 3b). When subjected to calcination at 800 Â°C (Mn8), these agglomerates grew uniformly. These agglomerates tended to have a hexagonal plate morphology and had smoother surfaces, which is characteristic of these types of materials. These observations are consistent with the crystal size/temperature increment relation showed by XRD ( Figure 2, Table 1) and Rietveld refinement ( Table 2).
